TF053327-PHRD-SERBIA AND MONTENEGRO:
            MONTENEGRO EDUCATION DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Reform Project
            for Montenegro were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Lessons learned
            include: with a loan in the amount of US$5 million
            equivalent, the World Bank was able to support an important
            reform in Montenegro, sharing its international experience
            and providing on-demand advice. By project closing, the
            Government had established a strong foundation for
            continuous improvements in primary and secondary education.
            While education reforms are complex to implement, projects
            do not have to be. The Government and the Bank's team
            designed a project that was simple and supported
            strategically selected interventions, thus focusing the
            Bank's resources in these areas. Information and data
            should be used as a tool to inform stakeholders and gain
            their support for difficult decisions that are part of the
            process. Stakeholder involvement in evaluation and planning,
            through governance bodies like the multi-donor steering
            committee for this project, is vital for successful and
            sustainable projects. Bank-financed projects that perform
            well are buoyed by strong commitment from the Government and
            stakeholders, complemented by clear project objectives and
            achievable outcomes.
